subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: It might be a subtilty of the creators... :) XP is more concerned about when tests break and why, versus how well they run.  The green bar is nice and gives us
messageBody:
It might be a subtilty of the creators... :)

XP is more concerned about when tests break and why, versus how well they
run. The green bar is nice and gives us (programmers) that lovely warm
feeling, but there's no comparison to the hideous response of the red bar.
It's like the difference betweed a shiny new BMW and a clunker that just
gets you from point A to point B. One does its job in the simplest way it
can without trying to show off at all, the other is all about showing off
(don't analyze the analogy to death - frankly I am not very good at them).
The reason we implemented the "enhancement" was for managament's sake
mostly. However, I guess there is something to be said about having a code
base of N classes and at least N asserts if not more. It makes you wonder
how well the code base is tested or designed when you have N/2 asserts.
Hmmm...

BTW: About the red bar, we also implemented (mostly for kicks and took it
out later) code that would play a really obnoxious .wav file when the red
bar showed up ("Cry havoc!! and let slip the dogs of war!" - from one of the
Star Trek movies [Christopher Plummer]). It was pretty exciting for a
while. :)

-Jason
